A Solana whale is doubling down despite being deep in the red.

Zooming out, this isn‚Äôt a one-off move.

Since August 22, 2025, the same whale has withdrawn and staked 1,231,861 SOL, originally worth $186.09 million. At today‚Äôs prices, that stash is now valued at $155.68 million, translating to an unrealized loss of $30.4 million.

And yet‚Ä¶ no panic. No rage-selling. Just more staking.

Either this whale has:

Absolute conviction in Solana‚Äôs long-term future 

A very long time horizon 

Or diamond fins stronger than most of us have hands 

Whales don‚Äôt always get it right, but they definitely don‚Äôt flinch easily.
For me, I see something fishy.

When overlaying BTC weekend price action,
most cases show little directional conviction,
remaining within a range or limited to temporary noise.

Weekends, with thinner liquidity, are
not a time when trends are born,
but rather a time when positions get adjusted.

The real direction often emerges
as liquidity returns from Monday onward.
There‚Äôs no need to overinterpret weekend moves.

According to Crypto Rover (@cryptorover),
Bitcoin may go through phases of lower short-term returns,
but investors who held over the long term have consistently remained profitable.

The key is not to be swayed by short-term price fluctuations,
but to approach the market with time on your side.

This chart overlays Bitcoin‚Äôs price path from cycle lows
across multiple past cycles.

What the red highlighted area shows is a time-consuming consolidation phase
that followed strong upside moves in previous cycles.

The key takeaway is this:
a major top does not necessarily mean an immediate collapse.
More often, Bitcoin enters a long adjustment phase,
with lower volatility at elevated price levels.

The current market feels similar‚Äî
less like a sudden crash,
and more like a war of attrition.

This is a phase to focus less on price itself,
and more on time and shifts in supply‚Äìdemand dynamics.

Bitcoin demand is softening slightly.

In this cycle, there have been three major demand waves,
and the most recent one appears to be peaking and rolling over.

Since early October, demand has remained below its trend,
which makes this a phase where BTC price can face short-term headwinds.

This is not a breakdown in fundamentals,
but rather a pause in supply‚Äìdemand dynamics.

We are now in a phase of identifying where the next source of demand will emerge.

üö® LONG-TERM BITCOIN HOLDERS ARE DUMPING ALL THEIR COINS

Why is that crazy?

Because they‚Äôre the people who usually NEVER SELL.

And you can literally see it in this chart.

They‚Äôre losing confidence in the markets.

Let me explain exactly what‚Äôs going on right now:

‚Äì Black line = BTC price
‚Äì Purple line = Long-Term Holder (LTH) supply
‚Äì Green/Red bars = the 30-day change in LTH supply (net accumulation vs net distribution)

When the bars are green, long-term holders are adding (they‚Äôre absorbing supply).

When the bars flip red, they‚Äôre distributing (they‚Äôre dumping coins into the market).

Now look at the right side of the chart, it‚Äôs not just one red candle, but THREE.

That means: the group that normally sits tight is NET SELLING.

Why that matters:

Long-term holders are defined around the ‚Äúheld for ~155 days‚Äù threshold in most on-chain frameworks.

After that point, coins statistically become way less likely to move.

So when they do move?

It‚Äôs usually for one of two reasons:

Is Bitcoin really being ‚Äúheld back‚Äù by liquidity?
Or are we misreading what this phase actually represents?

Recent price action points less to macro constraints and more to market structure. After a sharp repricing earlier in the cycle, positioning reset and risk appetite recalibrated. What followed was not capitulation, but gradual supply redistribution, mainly from long-term holders monetizing past accumulation.

Does this mean the long-term thesis is weakening?
Not quite. It suggests that, in the current regime, Bitcoin is no longer the asset with the highest marginal return for global capital. When alternative assets offer clearer short-term payoff or stronger narratives, capital rotates. That‚Äôs how cycles work.

Are derivatives suppressing price?
They shape volatility at the margin, but the persistence and scale of this range are consistent with spot-driven flows, not leverage constraints. ETF data reinforces this: selling pressure remains largely internal to crypto, not imposed from outside.

Are macro tailwinds finally turning supportive?
Yes, conditions are gradually shifting. Looser policy and more expansionary fiscal stances matter, but as context, not as immediate catalysts. Liquidity doesn‚Äôt flip switches; it amplifies what‚Äôs already underway.

Does Bitcoin react to a single driver at a time?
Rarely. Its behavior reflects market regimes, not isolated inputs.

And what regime are we in now?
One of digestion and balance. Capital is being absorbed, not rushed.

When that regime changes, the signal won‚Äôt be subtle.
Price will adjust first, the narrative will catch up later.
